content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice puzzle !!!

You should define what a misplaced number is.

From your code and what I assumed at first, it would make sense that misplaced numbers cannot be counted as misplaced twice. Ex:

11xx
xxx1

This should count as 1 misplaced number.

Your test cases, however, do not check for this at all. A player can pass all the test cases and validators simply by counting the numbers of numbers in the first line that appear in the second line.

✅ Approved the contribution.
I approve your Clash.
I like this game and your proposal is doable in less than 5min.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice way of turning Mastermind into the boundaries of a Clash. Doable in <5min, and after that enough minutes are left for code optimization in shortest mode.

Nice clash! Do you have a specific reason not to include Shortest mode? This clash needs a bit more than one line of code for a solution - generally I like that in a Shortest as well, because it gives more room for variation.

Similar clash already exists:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/1567c528157b2895218b4fcbcb3964ba226f

Maybe change your output requirement to something else? For example, {{WIN}} if the guess is the same as the code, otherwise the number of correctly guessed digits.

In addition, in Goal section, please change "numbers"/"number" to "digits"/"digit" (7 times).

Thanks.

Maybe add more examples to show the cases when you have one misplaced number:
solution       1121
proposition 1333
x

solution       1121
proposition 1313
xo
What is the good practice on the examples? Can I add a few in the statement (I added them to see how it looks).
Thank you for these good instructions. Corrections made :)

THANKS ! I thought the exercise was too complex to add code size optimization. But, indeed, the exercise would be interesting to solve in a minimum of characters. I  just added this possibility. I'm curious to see your shortest solution :)

Thank you for this feedback!
In fact, this specific case is well shown in the statement:
Line 1: 1121
Line 2: 3313
Output: o

In the test sets, we have this one which is close to your example:
Line 1: 4164
Line 2: 3724
Output: x

I added a test set that checks this specific case ;)

I also added a precision on the concept of misplaced.

Whoops missed the example.

The 9th test case was a good idea, as it stops the thing I mentioned before. Unfortunately, I can just count the numbers of numbers in the second line that appear in the first line now (swapped the vars)
I added a test by inverting the proposition containing the same digit twice ;)

Best I can get with this one currently is 141 characters (Python) - but it keeps nagging me, which I like.
Indeed this exercise is not designed for code size optimization - but that is part of the fun; there are multiple parts of the code in which you can try to make it short. I like that more than the clashes for which the solution can be simply one line, and winning shortest comes simply down to knowing chr and ord.

Thank you for making the changes.

Goal section
* Please delete "f" after "WIN".

* Please change "badly-placed" to "misplaced".

* Please mention that other wrong digits are ignored.

Output section
* Please add "{{WIN}} if the guess is correct, or" in the description.

* Please change "well or badly placed" to "well-placed or misplaced".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks again.
Thank you for your help !
When you include examples in Goal section please also include a bit of explanation of the expected output. Otherwise it's just a duplicate of Example section and the cases.
I added an introductory sentence to the examples, and highlighted the numbers present in the two combinations, to clarify and give added value to the examples.
That definitely looks better! I'd further suggest to change the [[variable]] format to either <<bold>> or {{constant}} format when highlighting the well-placed/misplaced digits.
It's done ! Thank you again for the advice :)
